unnormalised: Okay, so, like, everyone's been buzzing about the Chandrayaan-3 mission, right? I mean, it was HUGE! But did you catch the finer deets about the timeline? I was digging around online last night, procrastinating on my mom's Diwali shopping list, and stumbled upon some interesting stuff.
normalised: Okay, so, like, everyone's been buzzing about the Chandrayaan-3 mission, right? I mean, it was HUGE! But did you catch the finer details about the timeline? I was digging around online last night, procrastinating on my mom's Diwali shopping list, and stumbled upon some interesting stuff.

unnormalised: First off, remember the launch? It was on 14/07/2023 at 2:35 PM IST. Seriously, I remember watching it live with my whole family. My little cousin was, like, jumping up and down! They had initially planned for, you know, a possible launch window stretching back a few days, but the 14th was the confirmed date after all those tests.
normalised: First off, remember the launch? It was on fourteenth july two thousand and twenty three at two thirty five P-M I-S-T. Seriously, I remember watching it live with my whole family. My little cousin was, like, jumping up and down! They had initially planned for, you know, a possible launch window stretching back a few days, but the fourteenth was the confirmed date after all those tests.

unnormalised: Then, there was that nail-biting descent. It seems like ages ago, but the Vikram lander finally touched down on the moon's surface on 23/08/2023 around 6:04 PM IST. Can you imagine the pressure on those scientists? I bet they were mainlining chai like crazy! My friend said she was glued to the TV for the whole thing, forgetting to eat dinner until after 9:00 PM.
normalised: Then, there was that nail-biting descent. It seems like ages ago, but the Vikram lander finally touched down on the moon's surface on twenty third august two thousand and twenty three around six zero four P-M I-S-T. Can you imagine the pressure on those scientists? I bet they were mainlining chai like crazy! My friend said she was glued to the T-V for the whole thing, forgetting to eat dinner until after nine zero zero P-M.

unnormalised: What blew my mind was how precisely they timed everything. The entire mission, from launch to touchdown, took roughly 41 days. I mean, think about the calculations involved! I barely manage to calculate my monthly budget and that's a total disaster!
normalised: What blew my mind was how precisely they timed everything. The entire mission, from launch to touchdown, took roughly forty one days. I mean, think about the calculations involved! I barely manage to calculate my monthly budget and that's a total disaster!

unnormalised: Someone was mentioning that the Pragyan rover was only supposed to be operational for 14 Earth days. Which, honestly, seemed kinda short to me at first. Turns out, that was roughly equivalent to one lunar day because that’s how long the sunlight would last in that location.
normalised: Someone was mentioning that the Pragyan rover was only supposed to be operational for fourteen Earth days. Which, honestly, seemed kinda short to me at first. Turns out, that was roughly equivalent to one lunar day because that’s how long the sunlight would last in that location.

unnormalised: I also read something about how ISRO declared the mission objectives to be complete around 02/09/2023. But, like, the experiments and data collection kept going, right? I guess they extracted as much as possible from the available sunlight, before the long lunar night descended.
normalised: I also read something about how I-S-R-O declared the mission objectives to be complete around second september two thousand and twenty three. But, like, the experiments and data collection kept going, right? I guess they extracted as much as possible from the available sunlight, before the long lunar night descended.

unnormalised: Now, the part where things got kinda dicey – around 04/09/2023, they put the lander and rover into sleep mode, hoping they'd wake up when the sun came back. I'm keeping my fingers crossed that happens. I heard someone say the lunar day began again around 22/09/2023, so they're probably trying to re-establish contact.
normalised: Now, the part where things got kinda dicey – around fourth september two thousand and twenty three, they put the lander and rover into sleep mode, hoping they'd wake up when the sun came back. I'm keeping my fingers crossed that happens. I heard someone say the lunar day began again around twenty second september two thousand and twenty three, so they're probably trying to re-establish contact.

unnormalised: So yeah, that's basically my late-night Chandrayaan-3 timeline deep dive. Pretty impressive, no? Makes you feel proud to be Indian, doesn’t it? I’m prepping for future events and thinking of setting reminders for myself based on the lunar calendar, starting 10/10/2024 for the next eclipse. Now, back to that Diwali shopping… Wish me luck!
normalised: So yeah, that's basically my late-night Chandrayaan-3 timeline deep dive. Pretty impressive, no? Makes you feel proud to be Indian, doesn’t it? I’m prepping for future events and thinking of setting reminders for myself based on the lunar calendar, starting tenth october two thousand and twenty four for the next eclipse. Now, back to that Diwali shopping… Wish me luck!
